before_start: {"blocks":[{"key":"f9jvl","text":"The generation of juvenile sporophyte material for isotopic labelling can be achieved through various methods, such as sampling from the field or growing sporophytes from spores or vegetative stock gametophytes. For details of our experiment see PLOS ONE article. Juvenile kelp sporophytes for labelling purposes have to be cultured in a way, which ensures good growth to produce actively growing healthy material. The following steps are tailored to the two species cultivated for this experiment and may require adaptation based on the available equipment and sporophyte physiology.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":246,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

description: {"blocks":[{"key":"4qcc3","text":"Isotope tracing experiments can be used to trace organic material flow through the ecosystem by artificially adding labelled biomass into a system. The advantage of this process is the direct control of carbon and nitrogen addition to the system for measuring uptake rates by consumers which can substantially reduce the uncertainties associated with food web models. This protocol details the steps involved in successfully culturing and isotopically enriching (13C \u0026 15N) juvenile sporophytes of two common North Atlantic kelp species (Laminariales): Saccharina latissima and Laminaria digitata. A first-order successful isotopic enrichment study of S. latissima, as well as the first inclusion of 15N enrichment for L. digitata, is detailed. This protocol provides a comprehensive description of the stable isotope enrichment process in two kelp species, potentially serving as a foundation for its application in other macroalgal taxa.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":463,"length":2},{"style":"sup","offset":469,"length":2},{"style":"sup","offset":700,"length":2},{"style":"italic","offset":553,"length":20},{"style":"italic","offset":578,"length":18},{"style":"italic","offset":652,"length":12},{"style":"italic","offset":719,"length":11}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"16pn2","text":"Sterile culture bottles (glass or plexiglass) of sufficient size are used for cultivation. In our case, sporophytes of Laminaria digitata and Saccharina latissima were cultured in   DURAN glass bottles with the nutrient addition of   (half concentration) Provasoli Enriched Seawater (PES) in   fresh seawater stored in temperature-controlled laboratories at  . Medium was changed weekly and continuously bubbled with dry air via tubes. Irradiance should be set to around 40-50 µmol photons m-2 s-1 in long-day conditions (16 h light : 8 h dark; 16:8 LD). For cultivation of sporophytes, clean and pasteurised seawater is needed, either from natural fully marine sources or artificial seawater at approximately 30-33 PSU. Here, seawater was filtered through a 5\" Polypropylene Yarn Water Filter and was pasteurised for   at   with a combi steamer (PALUX, {"blocks":[{"key":"f02ct","text":"Incubation of sporophytes for labelling","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":39}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"19pns","text":"Selected kelp sporophytes are stored in Kautex bottles, filled with the pasteurized seawater and labelling solution to the top, tightly closed and placed on rotating or tilting shakers for 9 days. {"blocks":[{"key":"32v0u","text":"Separation of growing from non-growing blade parts","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":50}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fu0cb","text":"After the incubation period, newly formed blade parts of sporophytes normally become visible by a widening at the basis (see image below). We expected that the basal blade part that was formed during incubation would have a higher labelling result than the distal blade part. This assumption was supported by our results (see PLOS ONE article for details). Thus, if you cut sporophytes at the intersection between the estimated new growth (highly labelled) and prior biomass (slightly labelled), you separate material with a differential labelling result. {"blocks":[{"key":"5klon","text":"Macroalgal growth rates should be determined in simulated labelling conditions prior to labelling start to ensure the material is growing well. Otherwise, successful incorporation of labelled compounds is not guaranteed. Wet weight (mg) and surface area (cm2) are the main variables that should be measured at regular intervals (e.g. every 4 days), but blade length can also be used as a variable. In addition, pH measurements can be taken to monitor the acidity of the media.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":257,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4c204","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"etf00","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4mbjs","text":"To ensure uptake of enriched chemicals, the algal biomass should ideally double during the labelling period. {"blocks":[{"key":"fef7q","text":"Example incubation of sporophytes for determining growth rates","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":62}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"sjfb","text":"Either two sporophytes of Saccharina latissima or four sporophytes of Laminaria digitata were placed into a single   Kautex bottle (ensure sufficient replication). Wet weight (mg), surface area (cm2) and pH were measured in 4-day intervals for a 14-day period.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":26,"length":20},{"style":"italic","offset":70,"length":18},{"style":"sup","offset":197,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":115,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"9un9a","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"23kke","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9n79b","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"8c6qr","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dta4q","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":3,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"dkdmk","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"amount","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"2","error":false,"guid":"","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":3}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":8,"offset":150,"style":"italic"},{"length":12,"offset":374,"style":"italic"},{"length":13,"offset":390,"style":"italic"},{"length":12,"offset":497,"style":"italic"},{"length":13,"offset":513,"style":"italic"},{"length":12,"offset":565,"style":"italic"},{"length":11,"offset":602,"style":"italic"}],"key":"1b3gb","text":"The number of sporophytes placed into the 2 L Kautex bottles will depend on (a) the amount of enriched organic matter needed for the incubations (see PLOS ONE article for example), (b) the size of the pre-labelling sporophytes and (c) the ratio between sporophyte size and bottles. For this experiment, we used sporophytes of approximately 11 cm and 4 cm length of a single S. latissima and L. digitata thallus. The average wet weight of a single sporophyte was approximately 104 mg and 24 mg for S. latissima and L. digitata respectively. Thus, two sporophytes of S. latissima and four sporophytes of L. digitata were placed into a Kautex bottle each. In case that you need more material or sporophytes are bigger, you should also increase the size of the incubation bottles to ensure good growth.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{},"guid":"A4CC23A648564EAEA13C182A6626C0E5"}},"2":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":1,"offset":331},{"key":1,"length":1,"offset":428},{"key":2,"length":1,"offset":455}],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":1,"offset":89,"style":"bold"}],"key":"a0po4","text":"In case you use new Kautex bottles, which are made from polyethylene terephthalate glycol (PETG), you have to take care to reduce the risk of contamination. To reduce the impact of the new PETG material and polyethylene (PE) foam insert of the closures on the macroalgae, the bottles were filled with tap water, closed and stored    . This was followed by washing the closures and bottles in the dishwasher without detergent at   and dried in the oven at   .","type":"unstyled"}],"collapsed":true,"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"duration":0,"guid":"E1C3365089AC11ECA6BC4917D74714C6","id":0,"label":"","pause":null,"preset":["overnight"],"start":null},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"duration"},"1":{"data":{"duration":0,"error_temperature":false,"guid":"ED47AB0089AC11ECA6BC4917D74714C6","id":0,"label":"","pause":null,"preset":["overnight"],"scientificNotation":false,"start":null,"temperature":"50","unit":10},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"temperature"},"2":{"data":{"duration":0,"error_temperature":false,"guid":"F38C484089AC11ECA6BC4917D74714C6","id":0,"label":"","pause":null,"preset":["overnight"],"scientificNotation":false,"start":null,"temperature":"40","unit":10},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"temperature"}},"guid":"A3B5C1808FF511EC98AC91C477BF9554"}},"3":{"type":"equipment","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"brand":"Kautex","can_edit":1,"file":{"icon":"","id":null,"name":"","source":""},"guid":"452A1E2D341F11EE9D4302C0B41BC903","image":{"icon":"","id":null,"name":"","source":""},"link":"https://www.analytics-shop.com/gb/","name":"Wide Necked square container, PETG, 2000mL w/ screw closure, crystal clear","sku":"225274374","specifications":null,"type":"Wide neck container","vendor":{"id":1398,"image":{"placeholder":"/img/vendors/placeholder.png","source":"/img/vendors/placeholder.png"},"is_requested":false,"link":"https://www.analytics-shop.com/gb/","name":"Analytics Shop"}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"ei3av","text":"Pre-labelling start conditions","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":30}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"85qrp","text":"A few days prior to labelling start, full PES (  PES in   pasteurized seawater) should be added and irradiance should be set to 50 µmol photons m-2 s-1 to induce optimum growth rates (16 h light : 8 h dark per 24-hour period).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":145,"length":3},{"style":"sup","offset":149,"length":3}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":47,"length":1},{"key":1,"offset":56,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"4dir4","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"7l4j1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"amount","mutability":"","data":{"amount":"200","error":false,"guid":"FDD14D628FF211EC911B0A58A9FEAC02","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":2}},"1":{"type":"amount","mutability":"","data":{"amount":"10","error":false,"guid":"FDD14DE68FF211EC911B0A58A9FEAC02","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":3}},"2":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"fje4v","text":"Depending on species and developmental stage the conditions for inducing optimum growth rates may vary.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

For details of the results for this experiment see PLOS ONE article.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":24,"length":2},{"style":"sup","offset":32,"length":2},{"style":"italic","offset":97,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5h4p5","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"epvbn","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":32,"offset":0}],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":2,"offset":49,"style":"sup"},{"length":2,"offset":57,"style":"sup"},{"length":2,"offset":247,"style":"sup"},{"length":2,"offset":255,"style":"sup"},{"length":2,"offset":1527,"style":"sup"},{"length":2,"offset":1545,"style":"sup"},{"length":1,"offset":702,"style":"sub"},{"length":1,"offset":710,"style":"sub"}],"key":"anfeo","text":"UC Davis Stable Isotope Facility (SIF) performed 13C and 15N isotope analyses using an elemental analyser interfaced to a continuous flow isotope ratio mass spectrometer (IRMS). As per UC Davis SIF guidelines, small plant samples are analysed for 13C and 15N isotopes using a PDZ Europa ANCA-GSL elemental analyser interfaced to a PDZ Europa 20-20 isotope ratio mass spectrometer (Sercon Ltd., Cheshire, UK). Samples are combusted at 1000°C in a reactor packed with chromium oxide and silvered copper oxide. Following combustion, oxides are removed in a reduction reactor (reduced copper at 650°C). The helium carrier then flows through a water trap (magnesium perchlorate and phosphorous pentoxide). N2 and CO2 are separated from the samples via a Carbosieve GC column prior to entering the IRMS. Calibrated reference materials are added to the samples during analysis. During analysis, the samples are interspersed with multiple replicates of at least four distinct laboratory reference materials. These reference materials have undergone prior calibration against internationally recognized standards, including IAEA-600, USGS-40, USGS-41, USGS-42, USGS-43, USGS-61, USGS-64, and USGS-65. A sample's initial isotope ratio is assessed relative to a reference gas peak, which is analyzed alongside each sample. These initial values are then refined by adjusting them for the entire batch using the established values of the laboratory reference materials included in the analysis. Standard deviations are figured at 0.2 ‰ for 13C and 0.3 ‰ for 15N. The final delta values are expressed relative to international standards VPDB (Vienna Pee Dee Belemnite) and Air for carbon and nitrogen, respectively.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"guid":"4FFC4ED0D23F11EEADD70A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://stableisotopefacility.ucdavis.edu"},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"link"}}}}}}
